maml:description.maml:para: Exports a DSC configuration from Automation to a local file.

The Export-AzureRmAutomationDscConfiguration cmdlet exports an Azure PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) configuration from Azure Automation to a local file. The exported file has a .ps1 file name extension.
Specifies the name of a resource group for which this cmdlet exports a DSC configuration.
Specifies the name of the Automation account that contains the DSC that this cmdlet exports.
Indicates that this cmdlet replaces an existing local file with a new file that has the same name.
Specifies the output folder where this cmdlet exports the DSC configuration.

Specifies which version of the DSC configuration that this cmdlet exports. Valid values are:
-- Draft -- Published
The default value is Published.
Specifies the name of the DSC configuration that this cmdlet exports.
Specifies the name of the Automation account that contains the DSC that this cmdlet exports.
Indicates that this cmdlet replaces an existing local file with a new file that has the same name.
Specifies the name of the DSC configuration that this cmdlet exports.
Specifies the output folder where this cmdlet exports the DSC configuration.
Specifies the name of a resource group for which this cmdlet exports a DSC configuration.

Specifies which version of the DSC configuration that this cmdlet exports. Valid values are:
-- Draft -- Published
The default value is Published.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Export the published version of a DSC configuration

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports the published version of a DSC configuration in Automation to the specified folder, which is the desktop.

maml:description.maml:para: Exports the raw content of a DSC report sent from a DSC node to Automation.
The Export-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReportContent cmdlet exports the raw contents of an Azure PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) report. A DSC node sends a DSC report to Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of a resource group. This cmdlet exports the contents of a report for the DSC node that belongs to the resource group that this cmdlet specifies.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports report content for a DSC node that belongs to the Automation account that this parameter specifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet replaces an existing local file with a new file that has the same name.
Specifies the output folder where this cmdlet exports report contents.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet exports report contents.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node report that this cmdlet exports.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports report content for a DSC node that belongs to the Automation account that this parameter specifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet replaces an existing local file with a new file that has the same name.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet exports report contents.
Specifies the output folder where this cmdlet exports report contents.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node report that this cmdlet exports.
Specifies the name of a resource group. This cmdlet exports the contents of a report for the DSC node that belongs to the resource group that this cmdlet specifies.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Export a report from a DSC node
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Node = Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNode -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "AutomationAccount01" -Name "Computer14" PS C:\> $Report = Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReport -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "ContosoAutomationAccount" -NodeId $Node.Id -Latest PS C:\> $Report | Export-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReportContent -OutputFolder "C:\Users\PattiFuller\Desktop"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This set of commands exports the latest report from the DSC node named Computer14 to the desktop.

maml:description.maml:para: Exports an Automation runbook.

The Export-AzureRmAutomationRunbook cmdlet exports an Azure Automation runbook to a Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 ) file, for Windows PowerShell or Windows PowerShell Workflow runbooks, or to a graphical runbook (.graphrunbook) file, for graphical runbooks. The name of the runbook becomes the name of the exported file.
Specifies the name of the resource group for which this cmdlet exports a runbook.
Specifies the name of the Automation account in which this cmdlet exports a runbook.
Specifies the name of the runbook that this cmdlet exports. The name of the runbook becomes the name of the export file.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the path of a folder in which this cmdlet creates the export file.

Specifies whether this cmdlet exports the draft or published content of the runbook. Valid values are:
-- Published -- Draft
Specifies the name of the Automation account in which this cmdlet exports a runbook.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the runbook that this cmdlet exports. The name of the runbook becomes the name of the export file.
Specifies the path of a folder in which this cmdlet creates the export file.
Specifies the name of the resource group for which this cmdlet exports a runbook.

Specifies whether this cmdlet exports the draft or published content of the runbook. Valid values are:
-- Published -- Draft

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Export a runbook

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports the published version of an Automation runbook to a user desktop.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets reports sent from a DSC node to Automation.
The Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReport cmdlet gets reports sent from an Azure PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) node to Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of a resource group that contains the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports reports for a DSC node that belongs to the account that this parameter specifies.
Specifies an end time. This cmdlet gets reports that Automation received before this time.
Specifies a start time. This cmdlet gets reports that Automation received after this time.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of a resource group that contains the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports reports for a DSC node that belongs to the account that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node report for this cmdlet to get.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of a resource group that contains the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports reports for a DSC node that belongs to the account that this parameter specifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet gets the latest DSC report for the specified node only.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. This cmdlet exports reports for a DSC node that belongs to the account that this parameter specifies.
Specifies an end time. This cmdlet gets reports that Automation received before this time.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node report for this cmdlet to get.
Indicates that this cmdlet gets the latest DSC report for the specified node only.
Specifies the unique ID of the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies the name of a resource group that contains the DSC node for which this cmdlet gets reports.
Specifies a start time. This cmdlet gets reports that Automation received after this time.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all reports for a DSC node
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Node = Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNode -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Computer14" PS C:\> Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReport -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup14" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -NodeId $Node.Id

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the DSC node for the computer named Computer14 in the Automation account named Contoso17. The command stores this object in the $Node variable.

The second command gets metadata for all reports sent from the DSC node named Computer14 to the Automation account named Contoso17. The command specifies the node by using the Id property of the $Node object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a report for a DSC node by report ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Node = Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNode -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Computer14" PS C:\> Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReport -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -NodeId $Node.Id -Id c0a1718e-d8be-4fa3-91b6-82e1d3a36298

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the DSC node for the computer named Computer14 in the Automation account named Contoso17. The command stores this object in the $Node variable.
The second command gets metadata for the report identified by the specified ID sent from the DSC node named Computer14 to the Automation account named Contoso17.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get the latest report for a DSC node
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Node = Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNode -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Computer14" PS C:\> Get-AzureRmAutomationDscNodeReport -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup03" -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -NodeId $Node.Id -Latest

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the DSC node for the computer named Computer14 in the Automation account named Contoso17. The command stores this object in the $Node variable.
The second command gets metadata for the latest report sent from the DSC node named Computer14 to the Automation account named Contoso17.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates meta-configuration .mof files.

The Get-AzureRmAutomationDscOnboardingMetaconfig cmdlet creates Azure PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) meta-configuration Managed Object Format (MOF) files. This cmdlet creates a .mof file for each computer name that you specify. The cmdlet creates a folder for the .mof files. You can run the Set-DscLocalConfigurationManager cmdlet for this folder to onboard these computers into an Azure Automation account as DSC nodes.
Specifies the name of a resource group. This cmdlet creates .mof files to onboard computers in the resource group that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. You can onboard the computers that the ComputerName parameter specifies to the account that this parameter specifies.
Specifies an array of names of computers for which this cmdlet generates .mof files. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet generates an .mof file for the current computer (localhost).
Forces the command to run without prompting you for confirmation, and to replace existing .mof files that have the same name.
Specifies the name of a folder where this cmdlet stores .mof files.
Specifies the name of an Automation account. You can onboard the computers that the ComputerName parameter specifies to the account that this parameter specifies.
Specifies an array of names of computers for which this cmdlet generates .mof files. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet generates an .mof file for the current computer (localhost).
Forces the command to run without prompting you for confirmation, and to replace existing .mof files that have the same name.
Specifies the name of a folder where this cmdlet stores .mof files.
Specifies the name of a resource group. This cmdlet creates .mof files to onboard computers in the resource group that this parameter specifies.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Onboard servers to Automation DSC

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates DSC meta-configuration files for two servers for the Automation account named Contoso17. The command saves these files on a desktop.
The second command uses the Set-DscLocalConfigurationManager cmdlet to apply the meta-configuration to the specified computers to onboard them as DSC nodes.

Specifies the name of an Automation account for which this cmdlet gets job output.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Automation runbook jobs.
The Get-AzureRmAutomationJob cmdlet gets runbook jobs in Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of a resource group in which this cmdlet gets jobs.
Specifies the name of an Automation account for which this cmdlet gets jobs.

Specifies the end time for a job as a DateTimeOffset object. You can specify a string that can be converted to a valid DateTimeOffset. This cmdlet gets jobs that have an end time at or before the value that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the start time of a job as a DateTimeOffset object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a start time at or after the value that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the status of a job. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a status matching this parameter. Valid values are:
-- Activating -- Completed -- Failed -- Queued -- Resuming -- Running -- Starting -- Stopped -- Stopping -- Suspended -- Suspending
Specifies the name of a resource group in which this cmdlet gets jobs.
Specifies the name of an Automation account for which this cmdlet gets jobs.
Specifies the ID of a job that this cmdlet gets.

maml:description.maml:para: Imports an Automation runbook.

The Import-AzureRmAutomationRunbook cmdlet imports an Azure Automation runbook. Specify the path to a Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 ) file to import for Windows PowerShell and Windows PowerShell Workflow runbooks, or to a graphical runbook (.graphrunbook) file for graphical runbooks. The name of the file becomes the name of the runbook; however, for PowerShell, GraphicalPowerShell, and GraphicalPowerShellWorkflow runbook types the name can be specified during import by using the Name parameter. For Windows PowerShell Workflow runbooks, the script must contain a single Windows PowerShell Workflow definition that matches the name of the file.

-- PowerShell -- GraphicalPowerShell -- PowerShellWorkflow -- GraphicalPowerShellWorkflow -- Graph (obsolete; equivalent to GraphicalPowerShellWorkflow)

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Import a runbook from a file
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Tags = @{"tag01"='value01"; "tag02"="value02"} PS C:\> Import-AzureRmAutomationRunbook -Path .\GraphicalRunbook06.graphrunbook -Tags $Tags -ResourceGroup "ResourceGroup01" -AutomationAccountName "AutomationAccount01" -Type GraphicalPowerShell

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command assigns two key/value pairs to the $Tags variable.
The second command imports a graphical runbook called GraphicalRunbook06 into the Automation account named AutomationAccount01. The command also assigns the tags stored in $Tags.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Automation account.
The New-AzureRmAutomationAccount cmdlet creates an Azure Automation account in a resource group.

An Automation account is a container for Automation resources that is isolated from the resources of other Automation accounts. Automation resources include runbooks, Desired State Configuration (DSC) configurations, jobs, and assets.

Specifies the location in which this cmdlet creates the Automation account. To obtain valid locations, use the Get-AzureRMLocation cmdlet.

Specifies the plan for the Automation account. Valid values are:
-- Basic -- Free

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a new certificate
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Password = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "Password" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationCertificate -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "ContosoCertificate" -Path "./cert.pfx" -Password $Password -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command converts a plain text password to be a secure string by using the ConvertTo-SecureString cmdlet. The command stores that object in the $Password variable.
The second command creates a certificate named ContosoCertificate. The command uses the password stored in $Password. The command specifies the account name and the path of the file that it uploads.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Automation credential.
The New-AzureRmAutomationCredential cmdlet creates a credential as a PSCredential object in Azure Automation.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a credential
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$User = "Contoso\PFuller" PS C:\> $Password = ConvertTo-SecureString "Password" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> $Credential = New-Object -TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList $User, $Password PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationCredential -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "ContosoCredential" -Value $Credential -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command assigns a user name to the $User variable.
The second command converts a plain text password into a secure string by using the ConvertTo-SecureString cmdlet. The command stores that object in the $Password variable.
The third command creates a credential based on $User and $Password, and then stores it in the $Credential variable.
The final command creates an Automation credential named ContosoCredential that uses $Credential.

maml:description.maml:para: Imports a module into Automation.

The New-AzureRmAutomationModule cmdlet imports a module into Azure Automation. This command accepts a compressed file that has a .zip file name extension. The file contains a folder that includes a file that is one of the following types:
-- Windows PowerShell module, which has a .psm1 or .dll file name extension -- Windows PowerShell module manifest, which has a .psd1 file name extension
The name of the .zip file, the name of the folder, and the name of the file in the folder must be the same.
Specify the .zip file as a URL that the Automation service can access.

If you import a Windows PowerShell module into Automation by using this cmdlet or the Set-AzureRMAutomationModule cmdlet, the operation is asynchronous. The command finishes whether the import succeeds or fails. To check whether it succeeded, run the following command:
PS C:\> $ModuleInstance = Get-AzureRmAutomationModule -Name ModuleName
Check the ProvisioningState property for a value of Succeeded.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a one-time schedule in your machine's local time.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the time zone ID from the system.
The second command creates a schedule that runs one time on the current date at 11:00 PM in your local time zone.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a recurring schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $StartTime = Get-Date "13:00:00" PS C:\> $EndTime = $StartTime.AddYears(1) PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationSchedule -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Schedule02" -StartTime $StartTime -ExpiryTime $EndTime -DailyInterval 1 -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $StartDate variable. Specify a time that is at least five minutes in the future.
The second command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $EndDate variable. The command specifies a future time.
The final command creates a daily schedule named Schedule01 to begin at the time stored in $StartDate and expire at the time stored in $EndDate.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Create a recurring Weekly schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $StartTime = Get-Date "13:00:00" PS C:\> $EndTime = $StartTime.AddYears(1) PS C:\> $days = @([System.DayOfWeek]::Monday, [System.DayOfWeek]::Saturday, [System.DayOfWeek]::Sunday) PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationSchedule -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Schedule03" -StartTime $StartTime -ExpiryTime $EndTime -WeeklyInterval 1 -DaysOfWeek $days -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $StartDate variable. Specify a time that is at least five minutes in the future.
The second command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $EndDate variable. The command specifies a future time.
The third command creates an array of selected System.DayOfWeek in which the schedule is set to be run, and then stores the object in the $days variable.
The final command creates a weekly schedule named Schedule03 to begin at the time stored in $StartDate, expire at the time stored in $EndDate and run in the days of the week stored in $days.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Create a recurring Monthly schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $StartTime = Get-Date "13:00:00" PS C:\> $EndTime = $StartTime.AddYears(1) PS C:\> $days = @($days = @(17,19,25, "LastDay")) PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationSchedule -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Schedule04" -StartTime $StartTime -ExpiryTime $EndTime -MonthlyInterval 1 -DaysOfMonth $days -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $StartDate variable. Specify a time that is at least five minutes in the future.
The second command creates a date object by using the Get-Date cmdlet, and then stores the object in the $EndDate variable. The command specifies a future time.
The third command creates an array of selected System.Int in which the schedule is set to be run, and then stores the object in the $days variable.

The final command creates a monthlySchedule schedule named Schedule04 to begin at the time stored in $StartDate, expire at the time stored in $EndDate and run on the days of the month stored in $days.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a variable with a complex value
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$VirtualMachine = Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "VirtualMachine" -Name "VirtualMachine03" PS C:\> New-AzureRmAutomationVariable -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "ComplexVariable01" -Encrypted $False -Value $VirtualMachine -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a virtual machine by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command stores it in the $VirtualMachine variable.

The second command creates a variable named ComplexVariable01 in the Automation account named Contoso17. This command uses a complex object for its value, in this case, the virtual machine in $VirtualMachine.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a webhook

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a webhook named Webhook06 for the runbook named ContosoRunbook in the Automation account named AutomationAccount01. The command stores the webhook in the $Webhook variable. The webhook is enabled. The webhook expires at the specified time. This command does not provide any values for webhook parameters. This command specifies the Force parameter. Therefore, it does not prompt you for confirmation.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a webhook with parameters
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Params = @{"StringParam"="Hello World";"IntegerParam"=32} PS C:\> $Webhook = New-AzureRmAutomationWebhook -Name "Webhook11" -Parameters $Params -IsEnabled $True -ExpiryTime "10/2/2016" -RunbookName "ContosoRunbook" -ResourceGroup "ResourceGroup01" -AutomationAccountName "AutomationAccount01" -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates a dictionary of parameters, and stores them in the $Params variable.

The second command creates a webhook named Webhook11 for the runbook named ContosoRunbook in the Automation account named AutomationAccount01. The command assigns the parameters in $Params to the webhook.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a credential
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$User = "Contoso\DChew" PS C:\> $Password = ConvertTo-SecureString "Password" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> $Credential = New-Object -TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList $User, $Password PS C:\> Set-AzureRmAutomationCredential -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "ContosoCredential" -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" -Value $Credential

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command assigns a user name to the $User variable.
The second command converts a plain text password into a secure string by using the ConvertTo-SecureString cmdlet. The command stores that object in the $Password variable.
The third command creates a credential based on $User and $Password, and then stores it in the $Credential variable.
The final command modifies the Automation credential named ContosoCredential to use the credential in $Credential.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a module in Automation.

The Set-AzureRmAutomationModule cmdlet updates a module in Azure Automation. This command accepts a compressed file that has a .zip file name extension. The file contains a folder that includes a file that is one of the following types:
-- Windows PowerShell module, which has a .psm1 or .dll file name extension -- Windows PowerShell module manifest, which has a .psd1 file name extension
The name of the .zip file, the name of the folder, and the name of the file in the folder must be the same.
Specify the .zip file as a URL that the Automation service can access.

If you import a Windows PowerShell module into Automation by using this cmdlet or the New-AzureRMAutomationModule cmdlet, the operation is asynchronous. The command finishes whether the import succeeds or fails. To check whether it succeeded, run the following command:
PS C:\> $ModuleInstance = Get-AzureRmAutomationModule -Name ModuleName
Check the ProvisioningState property for a value of Succeeded.
Specifies the name of a resource group for which this cmdlet updates a module.
Specifies the name of the Automation account for which this cmdlet updates a module.
Specifies the name of the module that this cmdlet imports.
Specifies the URL of the .zip file that contains the new version of a module that this cmdlet imports.
Specifies the version of the module to which this cmdlet updates Automation.

Specifies the version of the module to which this cmdlet updates Automation.
